content: Chapter 154 of Title 28, United States Code, introduces special habeas corpus procedures in capital cases. Chapter 154 of Title 28, United States Code, introduces special habeas corpus procedures in capital cases. This chapter applies to cases under section 2254 brought by prisoners in State custody subject to a capital sentence, addressing the appointment of counsel and procedures for appointment. This chapter applies to cases under section 2254 brought by prisoners in State custody subject to a capital sentence, requiring the appointment of competent counsel in State post-conviction proceedings for indigent prisoners. The State must establish a mechanism for appointment, compensation, and payment of reasonable litigation expenses, with standards of competency for appointed counsel. Counsel appointed for indigent prisoners must not have previously represented the prisoner at trial or on direct appeal unless requested. Ineffectiveness of counsel in post-conviction proceedings is not grounds for relief in subsequent proceedings. In capital cases, the ineffectiveness of counsel during post-conviction proceedings is not a basis for relief under this chapter or section 2254. Different counsel can be appointed during these proceedings. A mandatory stay of execution can be granted upon application to the appropriate court, if the State has invoked post-conviction review procedures. A stay of execution can be granted upon application to the court if the State has invoked post-conviction review procedures. The stay expires if the prisoner fails to file a habeas corpus petition within the required time or if the petition for relief is denied after district court and court of appeals review. If relief is denied and the time for filing a petition for certiorari has expired or the Supreme Court denies the petition, or if a State prisoner under a capital sentence waives the right to pursue habeas corpus review, then no stay of execution can be granted. Habeas corpus review under section 2254 of this title must be done in the presence of counsel and after being advised of the consequences of waiving the right. No Federal court can enter a stay of execution or grant relief in a capital case unless the claim was not previously presented, the failure to raise the claim was due to State action violating the Constitution or laws, a new retroactively applicable Federal right was recognized by the Supreme Court, or the claim is based on new evidence.
